content: The "Perkins Modernization Act of 2014" is the short title of this Act, with the purpose outlined in Section 2. The Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Act of 2006 is amended to align students' skills with industry needs and ensure acquisition of relevant certifications and credentials. The Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Act of 2006 aims to align students' skills with industry needs and ensure they acquire relevant certifications and credentials based on labor market information. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Act of 2006 defines 'in-demand industry sector or occupation' as a sector or job that plays a significant role in the local economy, offers opportunities for economic self-sufficiency and advancement, and is supported by state labor market data. The determination of in-demand industry sectors or occupations is based on labor market information collected by State agencies, Federal agencies, local entities, workforce investment boards, or other third-party organizations engaged in research. Sectors and occupations can be identified as in-demand on a current or emerging basis. Labor market information describes current workforce demographics and projected trends. SEC. 4. Accountability is amended to focus on employment in in-demand industry sectors or occupations. SEC. 5. National activities. SEC. 5 of the Carl D. Section 124 of the Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Act of 2006 is amended to emphasize employment in in-demand industry sectors or occupations, including internships and equipment. The Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Act of 2006 is amended to prioritize employment in in-demand industry sectors or occupations by analyzing labor market information. The Carl D.
